{{unreferenced|date=February 2013}} {{Year nav topic5|1645|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1645'''.
==Events== * With the London theatres closed by the [[Puritan]] regime during the [[English Civil War]], [[closet drama]] grows in prominence. Henry Burkhead's ''Cola's Fury, or Lirenda's Misery'' is written in this genre and the sisters [[Jane Cavendish]] and [[Elizabeth Egerton]] probably complete their ''The Concealed Fansyes'' while besieged.
==New books== ===Prose=== * [[Edward Herbert, 1st Baron Herbert of Cherbury]] **''De Causis Errorum'' (On the Causes of Errors) **''De Religione Laici'' (On the Religion of the Laity) *[[John Milton]] **''[[Colasterion]]'' **''[[Tetrachordon]]'' *[[Elizabeth Richardson, Baroness Cramond]] – ''A Lady's Legacy to her Daughters'' *[[Alexander Ross (writer)|Alexander Ross]] **''Medicus Medicatus'' **''The Philosophical Touchstone'' *[[Francisco Manuel de Melo]] – ''Guerra de Cataluña'' *[[Horacio Carochi]] – ''[[Arte de la lengua mexicana con la declaración de los adverbios della|Arte de la lengua mexicana]]'' *[[Daniello Bartoli]] – ''[[L'huomo di lettere]]'' *[[Hermann Busenbaum]] – ''Medulla theologiae moralis''
===Drama=== *[[Luis Quiñones de Benavente]] – ''Jocoseria. Burlas veras, o reprensión moral y festiva de los desórdenes públicos'' *[[Molière]] – ''[[Le Médecin volant]]'' *[[Paul Scarron]] – ''Jodelet''
===Poetry=== *[[John Milton]] – ''[[Milton's 1645 Poems|Poems of Mr. John Milton, Both English and Latin, compos'd at several times]]'' (dated this year, published early 1646) *[[Sheikh Muhammad]] – ''Yoga-samgrama'' *[[Edmund Waller]] – ''Poems''
==Births== *[[August 16]] – [[Jean de La Bruyère]], French essayist (died [[1696 in literature|1696]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Edmund Bohun]], English historian, publicist and political writer (died [[1699 in literature|1699]])
==Deaths== *[[April 17]] – [[Daniel Featley]], English Calvinist theologian (born [[1582 in literature|1582]]) *[[August 28]] – [[Hugo Grotius]], Dutch polymath (born [[1583 in literature|1583]]) *[[August 31]] – [[Francesco Bracciolini]], Italian poet (born [[1566 in literature|1566]]) *[[September 8]] – [[Francisco de Quevedo]], Spanish nobleman, politician and poet (born [[1580 in literature|1580]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Feng Menglong]] (馮夢龍), Chinese vernacular poet and author (born [[1574 in literature|1574]]) **[[William Lithgow (traveller and author)|William Lithgow]], Scottish travel writer (born [[1582 in literature|1582]]) **[[John Paul Nazarius]], Italian Dominican theologian (born [[1556 in literature|1556]])
[[Category:1645 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

{{Year nav topic5|1697|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1697'''.
==Events== *[[May 7]] – The 13th century royal [[Tre Kronor (castle)|Tre Kronor]] ("Three Crowns") castle in [[Stockholm]] burns to the ground and a large portion of the royal library is destroyed. *The actors of the [[Comédie-Italienne]] in [[Paris]] announce a performance of ''La fausse prude'' (The False Hypocrite), a play that ridicules King [[Louis XIV of France]]'s wife, [[Françoise d'Aubigné, Marquise de Maintenon]], which causes the King to disband the company. *[[George Farquhar]] arrives in London from [[Dublin]]. *[[Thomas Corneille]] publishes his translation of [[Ovid]]'s ''[[Metamorphoses]]'' into French. *[[Daniel Defoe]]'s ''An Essay Upon Projects'' suggests insurance, an [[income tax]] and the education of women, among other public measures.<ref name=CBH>{{cite book|last=Palmer|first=Alan|last2=Palmer|first2=Veronica|year=1992|title=The Chronology of British History|publisher=Century Ltd|location=London|pages=200–201|isbn=0-7126-5616-2}}</ref> *First publication of the 13th century ''[[Heimskringla]]'' in [[Old Norse]], with [[Swedish language|Swedish]] and [[Latin]] translations by [[Johan Peringskiöld]] in Stockholm
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Mary Astell]] – ''A Serious Proposal to the Ladies, Part II'' *[[Pierre Bayle]] – ''{{lang|fr|[[Dictionnaire historique et critique]]}}'' (''Historical and Critical Dictionary'', first part, publication continued until 1702) *[[Richard Blackmore]] – ''King Arthur'' *[[Thomas Burnet]] – ''Remarks upon An Essay Concerning Humane Understanding'' (on [[John Locke]]) *[[William Congreve]] – ''The Birth of the Muse'' *[[William Dampier]] – ''A New Voyage Round the World'' *[[Daniel Defoe]] – ''An Essay Upon Projects'' *[[John Dryden]] **''[[Alexander's Feast (Dryden)|Alexander's Feast; or, The Power of Musique]]'' (ode) **''The Works of Virgil'' *[[John Evelyn]] – ''Numismata: A discourse of medals'' *[[Jane Lead]] – ''A Fountain of Gardens'' *[[John Locke]] **''A Letter to the Right Reverend Edward Ld Bishop of Worcester'' **''Mr Locke's Reply to the Right Reverend the Lord Bishop of Worcester's Answer to his Letter'' **''A Second Vindication of the Reasonableness of Christianity'' *[[Charles Perrault]] (as Pierre Perrault Darmancourt) – ''{{lang|fr|[[Histoires ou contes du temps passé|Histoires ou contes du temps passé, avec dez moralitez: Les Contes de ma Mère l'Oye]]}}'' (Tales and Stories of the Past with Morals: Tales of Mother Goose) *[[John Phillips (author)|John Phillips]] – ''{{lang|la|Augustus Britannicus}}'' *[[Humphrey Prideaux]] – ''The True Nature of Imposture Fully Display'd in the Life of Mahomet'' *[[John Wilmot, Earl of Rochester]] – ''Familiar Letters'' *[[William Wotton]] – ''Reflections upon Ancient and Modern Learning'' (setting off the English "quarrel of the Ancients and Moderns")
===Drama=== *Anonymous (A Young Lady) – ''The Unnatural Mother'' *[[Colley Cibber]] – ''Woman's Wit'' *[[William Congreve (playwright)|William Congreve]] – ''[[The Mourning Bride]]'' *[[John Dennis (dramatist)|John Dennis]] – ''A Plot and No Plot'' *Thomas Dilke – ''The City Lady, or Folly Reclaimed'' *[[Thomas D'Urfey]] **''Cinthia and Endimion'' (opera) **''The Intrigues at Versailles; or, A Jilt in all Humours'' *[[Charles Gildon]] – ''The Roman Brides Revenge'' *[[Charles Hopkins (poet)|Charles Hopkins]] – ''Boadicea Queen of Britain'' *[[Peter Anthony Motteux]] – ''The Novelty, or Every Act a Play'' *[[Mary Pix]] **''The Deceiver Deceiv'd'' **''The Innocent Mistress'' *[[George Powell (playwright)|George Powell]] – ''The Imposture Defeated, or a Trick to Cheat the Devil'' *[[Jacques Pradon]] – ''Scipion'' *[[Elkanah Settle]] – ''The World in the Moon'' *[[John Vanbrugh]] **''Aesop''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/playsvanbrugh01vanbuoft#page/222/mode/2up|title=''Esop''|publisher=Archive.org|accessdate=2012-03-22}}</ref> **''[[The Provoked Wife]]'' **''[[The Relapse]]'' (performed [[1696 in literature|1696]], published 1697)
==Births== *[[June 16]] – [[Jean-Baptiste de La Curne de Sainte-Palaye]], French historian, classicist and lexicographer (died [[1781 in literature|1781]]) *[[December 27]] – [[Sollom Emlyn]], Irish legal writer (died [[1754 in literature|1754]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Marie Anne de Vichy-Chamrond, marquise du Deffand|Madame du Deffand]], French literary hostess (died [[1780 in literature|1780]])
==Deaths== *[[February 5]] – [[Hester Biddle]] (Esther Biddle), English Quaker writer (born c. 1629) *[[March 1]] – [[Francesco Redi]], Tuscan physician, naturalist and poet (born [[1626 in literature|1626]]) *[[June 7]] – [[John Aubrey]], English memoirist (born [[1626 in literature|1626]]) *[[December 9]] – [[Scipion Abeille]], French surgeon and poet (year of birth unknown) *''Unknown date'' – [[Juan del Valle y Caviedes]], Spanish Peruvian poet (born [[1645 in literature|1645]]) *''Probable year of death'' – [[Gilbert Clerke]], English mathematician, natural philosopher and theologian (born [[1626 in literature|1626]])
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Year nav topic5|2005|art}}
The year '''2005 in [[art]]''' involves various significant events.
==Events== * June – [[Zentrum Paul Klee]], a museum dedicated to [[Paul Klee]], designed by [[Renzo Piano]], opens at [[Bern]] in [[Switzerland]]. *[[September 30]] – [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy|Controversial drawings of Muhammad]] are printed in the Danish newspaper [[Jyllands-Posten]].
==Awards== *[[Archibald Prize]] – [[John Olsen (Australian artist)|John Olsen]], ''Self portrait [[Janus (mythology)|Janus]] Faced'' *[[Beck's Futures]] – [[Christina Mackie]] *[[Caldecott Medal]] for children's book illustration – [[Kevin Henkes]], ''[[Kitten's First Full Moon]]'' *[[Rolf Schock Prizes|Rolf Schock Prize in Visual Arts]] – [[Kazuyo Sejima]] and [[Ryue Nishizawa]] *[[Turner Prize]] – [[Simon Starling]], ''Shedboatshed'' *The [[Venice Biennial]] (June 12 - November 6): **Lion d'Or [[Golden Lion]] for Lifetime Achievement: [[Barbara Kruger]] (USA) **Lion d'Or for Best Pavilion: [[Annette Messager]] (France) *[[Wynne prize]] – [[Jenny Sages]], ''The Road to Utopia''
==Works== {{See also|Category:2005 sculptures}} * February 12–27 – ''[[The Gates]]'', [[installation art]] by [[Christo and Jeanne-Claude]] in [[Central Park]], [[New York City]]. *[[May 10]] – Dedication of [[Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe]], designed by architect [[Peter Eisenman]] originally working with sculptor [[Richard Serra]] (both Americans), in Berlin. *[[July 9]] – Unveiling of [[Monument to the Women of World War II]], sculpted by [[John W. Mills]], in [[Whitehall]], [[London]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=David|title=Queen honours war's heroines|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/jul/10/secondworldwar.gender|accessdate=16 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=10 July 2005}}</ref> * [[Louise Bourgeois]] – ''[[Father and Son (Bourgeois)|Father and Son]]'' (sculpture in Seattle) * [[Herbert Dreiseitl]] – ''[[Artwall]]'' (installation art in Portland, Oregon) * [[Roy McMakin]] ** ''[[Love & Loss]]'' (installation art in Seattle) ** ''[[:File:McMakin's Throne.jpg|Untitled (Wooden Toilet)]]'' * [[Ron Mueck]] – ''[[:File:In Bed by Ron Mueck.png|In Bed]]'' (sculpture in [[Queensland Gallery of Modern Art]])<ref>{{cite book |title=Ron Mueck (Exhibition Catalog)|last=Hurlston|first=David|year=2010|publisher=National Gallery of Victoria|location=Melbourne|display-authors=etal}}</ref> * [[Odd Nerdrum]] – ''[[Cannibals (painting)|Cannibals]]'' * [[Dennis Oppenheim]] – ''[[Engagement (sculpture)|Engagement]]'' (sculptures) * [[Bridget Riley]] – ''Red Movement''
==Exhibitions== *[[Aleksander Balos]] – ''Travaux récents'' (organised by Arts nord sud, at Espace Griffon, Crédit Municipal, Paris, France)
==Deaths==
===January to March=== *[[1 January]] – [[Eugene J. Martin]], American [[visual art]]ist (b.[[1938 in art|1938]]). *[[4 January]] **<!--4 January-->[[Guy Davenport]], American writer, translator, illustrator, painter, intellectual and teacher (b.[[1927 in art|1927]]). **<!--4 January-->[[Alton Tobey]], American painter, [[historical artist]], muralist, [[portraitist]], illustrator and [[Art education|teacher]] (b.[[1914 in art|1914]]). *[[14 January]] **<!--14 January-->[[Conroy Maddox]], English [[surrealist]] painter, collagist, writer and lecturer (b.[[1912 in art|1912]]). **<!--14 January-->[[Rudolph Moshammer]], German fashion designer (b.[[1940 in art|1940]]). *[[25 January]] **<!--25 January-->[[Philip Johnson]], American major art collector, [[MoMA]] curator, influential architect (b. [[1906 in art|1906]]) **<!--25 January-->[[Max Velthuijs]], [[Dutch people|Dutch]] painter, illustrator and author (b.[[1923 in art|1923]]). *[[27 January]] **<!--27 January-->[[Gordon Lambert]], Irish art collector (b.[[1919 in art|1919]]). **<!--27 January-->[[Aurélie Nemours]], French painter (b.[[1910 in art|1910]]). *[[7 February]] – [[Paul Rebeyrolle]], French painter (b.[[1926 in art|1926]]). *[[18 February]] – [[Harald Szeemann]], Swiss [[curator]] and [[art history|art historian]] (b.[[1933 in art|1933]]). *[[21 February]] – [[Zdzisław Beksiński]], Polish painter, photographer, and [[fantasy art]]ist (b.[[1929 in art|1929]]). *[[15 March]] – [[Judith Scott (artist)|Judith Scott]], American outsider fiber sculptor (b.[[1943 in art|1943]]). *[[20 March]] – [[Walter Hopps]], American museum director and [[curator]] (b.[[1932 in art|1932]]).
===April to June=== *[[5 April]] **<!--5 April-->[[Dale Messick]], first American woman [[Print syndication|syndicated]] [[comic strip]] artist (b.[[1906 in art|1906]])<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/07/arts/07cnd-messick.html?hp&_r=0|title=Dale Messick, Cartoonist Who Created Brenda Starr, Dies at 98|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2005-04-07|accessdate=2015-03-03}}</ref> **<!--5 April-->[[Neil Welliver]], American painter (b.[[1929 in art|1929]]) *[[10 April]] – [[Carl Abrahams]], Jamaican painter (b.[[1911 in art|1911]]) *[[11 April]] – [[André François]], French cartoonist (b.[[1915 in art|1915]]) *[[13 April]] **<!--13 April-->[[Philip Pavia]], American [[Sculpture|sculptor]] (b.[[1912 in art|1912]])<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.brooklynrail.org/2005/12/art/a-tribute-to-philip-pavia-1912-2005|title=A Tribute to Philip Pavia (1912-2005)|work=[[The Brooklyn Rail]]|date=2005-12-10|accessdate=2015-03-03}}</ref> **<!--13 April-->[[Juan Zanotto]], Italian-born [[Argentina|Argentine]] comic book artist (b.[[1935 in art|1935]]) *[[19 April]] – [[Clement Meadmore]], Australian-born American sculptor (b.[[1929 in art|1929]]) *[[22 April]] – [[Eduardo Paolozzi]], Scottish-born sculptor and artist (b.[[1924 in art|1924]]) *[[27 May]] – [[Fay Godwin]], English landscape photographer (b.[[1931 in art|1931]]) *[[12 June]] – [[David Whitney]], American independent curator and art dealer (b.[[1939 in art|1939]]) *[[21 June]] – [[Alvin D. Loving|Al Loving]], African American abstract impressionist painter (b.[[1935 in art|1935]])
===July to December=== *[[22 July]] - [[Dragoš Kalajić]], [[Serbian people|Serbian]] painter (b. [[1943 in art|1943]]) *[[26 July]] – [[Robert Chapman Turner|Robert C. Turner]], American [[Pottery|potter]] (b.[[1913 in art|1913]]) *[[27 July]] – [[Al Held]], American [[Abstract expressionism|Abstract expressionist]] painter (b.[[1928 in art|1928]]) *[[1 August]] – [[Constant Nieuwenhuys]], Dutch painter, one of the innovators of [[Unitary Urbanism]] (b.[[1920 in art|1920]]) *[[16 August]] – [[Joe Ranft]], American [[Magic (illusion)|magician]], animation [[storyboard artist]] and voice actor (b.[[1960 in art|1960]]) *[[22 August]] – [[Juliet Pannett]], English portrait artist (b. [[1911 in art|1911]]) *[[26 August]] – [[Robert Denning]], American interior designer (b.[[1927 in art|1927]]) *[[22 October]] – [[Arman]], French-born American artist (b.[[1928 in art|1928]]) *[[28 October]] – [[Raymond Hains]], French artist and photographer (b.[[1926 in art|1926]]) *[[11 November]] – [[Patrick Anson, 5th Earl of Lichfield]], English photographer (b.[[1939 in art|1939]]) *[[2 December]] – [[Lillian Browse]], English art dealer and historian (born [[1906 in art|1906]])

{{YYYY music|2005}} {{Year nav topic5|2005|music}}<!--nav-box has "list all" yrs-->
This is a list of notable events in music that took place in the year 2005.
== Specific locations == *[[2005 in British music]] *[[2005 in Irish music]] *[[2005 in Norwegian music]] *[[2005 in South Korean music]] *[[2005 in Swiss music]]
== Specific genres == *[[2005 in classical music]] *[[2005 in country music]] *[[2005 in heavy metal music]] *[[2005 in hip hop music]] *[[2005 in Latin music]] *[[2005 in jazz]]
==Events==
===January=== *[[January 1]] – In most of Europe, copyright expired on a number of classic pop and rock'n'roll songs recorded in 1954 and earlier, including [[Bill Haley]]'s "[[Rock Around the Clock]]", and "Only You" by [[The Platters]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.idmonsters.com/archives/2004/07/copyright_law_a.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061116184339/http://www.idmonsters.com/archives/2004/07/copyright_law_a.php |archivedate=2006-11-16 |df= }}</ref> *[[January 7]] – Welsh [[Punk rock|punk]] band [[Mclusky]] officially announce their disbanding via their website. Weeks later, Welsh noisecore/punk band [[Jarcrew]] disband due to their drummer becoming a [[Jehovah's Witnesses|Jehovah's Witness]] – remnants of the two bands later went on to join forces and become [[Future of the Left]]. *[[January 13]] – [[Duran Duran]] begins their [[Astronaut (Duran Duran album)|Astronaut]] in [[London, England]]. *[[January 17]] – Prior to missing 2 live shows, [[Mike Tempesta]] is officially no longer part of [[Powerman 5000]] due to fighting with the band. *[[January 20]] – [[Leonard Slatkin]] conducts the debut concert of [[Philip Glass]]'s [[Symphony No. 7 (Glass)|Symphony No. 7 "Toltec]]". *[[January 22]] – The [[Tsunami Relief Cardiff|Tsunami Relief]] concert is held at the [[Millennium Stadium]], [[Cardiff]], Wales – the largest live music event in the UK since the [[Live Aid]] concert of 1985. Performers included [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Eric Clapton]], [[Jools Holland]], [[Manic Street Preachers]], [[Lulu (singer)|Lulu]], [[Aled Jones]], [[Charlotte Church]], [[Katherine Jenkins]], [[Feeder (band)|Feeder]], [[Snow Patrol]], [[Liberty X]]. *[[January 29]] – [[Avril Lavigne]], [[Chantal Kreviazuk]], the [[Barenaked Ladies]], [[Raine Maida]], and [[Sarah McLachlan]] conduct a concert in Vancouver, British Columbia, for [[humanitarian response to the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|tsunami relief]]. *[[January 31]] **[[Tiesto]] releases a new single from his album [[Just Be (album)|Just Be]] entitled [[Adagio for Strings (Tiesto song)|Adagio for Strings]]. **[[Jon Levasseur]] leaves [[Cryptopsy]], saying he has lost interest in Extreme Music.
===February=== *[[February 7]] – The [[BRIT Awards]] are held in London. [[Scissor Sisters]], [[Keane (band)|Keane]], [[Franz Ferdinand (band)|Franz Ferdinand]], and [[Joss Stone]] are among the winners. *[[February 8]] – [[Matchbox Twenty]] frontman [[Rob Thomas (musician)|Rob Thomas]] releases [[Lonely No More]], his first solo hit. It peaked at #1 in Adult Contemporary. *[[February 13]] – The [[47th Grammy Awards]] are held in [[Staples Center]], [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. [[Ray Charles]] become the big winner at the ceremony. [[Britney Spears]] earned her first [[Grammy]] in the category of [[Grammy Award for Best Dance Recording|Best Dance Recording]] for her hit single [[Toxic (song)|Toxic]]. *[[February 15]] – [[Sonny Mayo]] replaces [[Clint Lowery]] in [[Sevendust]]. *[[February 22]] **After being silent since late 2004, [[Blink-182]] announce that they will be taking an indefinite hiatus, the news comes as a big shock for fans. According to guitarist [[Tom DeLonge]], the band will not come completely inactive. **[[Brian Welch]], guitarist of [[KoЯn]], leaves the band after converting to Christianity. *[[February 28]] – [[Static-X]] fires [[Tripp Eisen]] because of his arrest for sex offenses involving a minor.
===March=== *[[March 7]] – [[Koichi Fukuda]] rejoins [[Static-X]] on guitar after 5 years away from the band. Fukuda replaces [[Tripp Eisen]], who was arrested twice in February over two separate charges of sexual intercourse with underage girls. *[[March 26]] – Australian drummer of [[Crowded House]], [[Paul Hester]], is found dead in a Melbourne Park. *[[March 29]] – [[Mariah Carey]] releases her second single, "[[We Belong Together]]", from her tenth studio album, ''[[The Emancipation of Mimi]]''. The song would hold the number one position on the Billboard Hot 100 for 14 weeks, the highest record for the entire decade. [[Will Smith]] releases his fourth studio album (first under Interscope Records) [[Lost and Found (Will Smith album)|''Lost and Found'']].
===April=== *[[April 3]] **[[Country music]] legend [[Kenny Rogers]] signs a major worldwide record deal with [[Capitol Records]]. **[[Alice in Chains]] original bass player [[Mike Starr (musician)|Mike Starr]] is arrested for "investigation of property destruction and theft". He was also sentenced to 30 days for misdemeanor drug possession in April 1994, two years after being replaced from the group during the recording of ''[[Dirt (Alice in Chains album)|Dirt]]''. *[[April 7]] – The concert [[Selena ¡VIVE!]] takes place at [[Reliant Stadium]] in Houston. The memorial concert was held on the 10th anniversary of the murder by firearm of Selena, "The Queen of Tejano Music". Performers include [[Thalía]], [[Gloria Estefan]], [[Paulina Rubio]], [[Pepe Aguilar]], [[Banda el Recodo]], [[Alejandra Guzmán]] and [[Fey (singer)|Fey]]. *[[April 9]] – [[Destiny's Child]] launch their World Tour [[Destiny Fulfilled ... And Lovin' It]] in [[Hiroshima, Japan]]. *[[April 12]] – [[Mariah Carey]] releases her tenth studio album, ''[[The Emancipation of Mimi]]''. The album went on to become the best-selling album of 2005 in the US, and the second-best seller worldwide, with global sales of 10 million copies.<ref>"Mariah Carey: Come in and smell the perfume". The Daily Telegraph. March 17, 2008. Retrieved October 7, 2017.</ref> Its second single, "[[We Belong Together]]", was later hailed "Song of the Decade" by ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''<ref>Trust, Gary (June 25, 2010). "Ask Billboard: Katy Perry, Christina Aguilera, Lady Gaga". Billboard. Retrieved February 5, 2011.</ref> and accumulated 14 weeks at number one in the US, while its third single, [[Shake It Off (Mariah Carey song)|"Shake It Off"]], reached number two. The album marked a career revival for the songstress and was her biggest success of the decade. *[[April 18]] – [[Kenneth Schermerhorn]] passes away at the age of 85. *[[April 19]] – [[Mike Jones (rapper)|Mike Jones]] releases his first studio album entitled "[[Who Is Mike Jones?]]" in the United States.
===May=== *May–June – [[Operation Ivy (band)|Operation Ivy]]/[[Rancid (band)|Rancid]] bassist [[Matt Freeman]] is diagnosed with lung cancer. *[[May 2]] **Legendary [[blues-rock]] group [[Cream (band)|Cream]] reunites for four shows in London's [[Royal Albert Hall]]. **[[Linkin Park]] issues a press release demanding to end its contract with [[Warner Music Group]], on the grounds that the label would fail to meet its "fiduciary responsibility to market and promote Linkin Park" due to cost-cutting efforts at the company.<ref name="linkin park">{{cite web |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=36191 |title=Linkin Park Refuses To Record For Warner |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=May 2, 2005 |work= |publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |accessdate=April 5, 2013}}</ref> *[[May 6]] – [[Audioslave]] becomes the first American rock group to perform a free outdoor concert in [[Cuba]]. *[[May 17]] – [[Kylie Minogue]] is diagnosed with breast cancer. Thus she has to cancel her [[Showgirl: The Greatest Hits Tour]]. *[[May 21]] – The Los Angeles radio station [[KROQ-FM]] airs the 13th Annual [[KROQ Weenie Roast|Weenie Roast]] show with [[Alkaline Trio]], [[Audioslave]], [[Bloc Party]], [[The Bravery]], [[The Dead 60s]], [[Foo Fighters]], [[Hot Hot Heat]], [[Interpol (band)|Interpol]], [[Jimmy Eat World]], [[The Killers]], [[The Mars Volta]], [[Mötley Crüe]], [[MxPx]], [[My Chemical Romance]], [[Queens of the Stone Age]] and [[Transplants (band)|The Transplants]]. *[[May 22]] – [[Tammin Sursok]] releases her debut and to date only album ''[[Whatever Will Be]]''. *[[May 23]] – [[Gorillaz]] release their second studio album, [[Demon Days]]. *[[May 25]] – [[Carrie Underwood]] wins the fourth season of ''[[American Idol]]''.
===June=== *[[June 4]] – [[Mariah Carey]]'s "[[We Belong Together (Mariah Carey song)|We Belong Together]]" became her sixteenth chart topper on the [[US Billboard Hot 100]]. The song then spent 14 non-consecutive weeks at number one on both the US ''Billboard'' [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]] and [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]] chart. It made history when it became the first song to simultaneously occupy the number one position on nine ''Billboard'' charts (the week ending August 6, 2005): the Hot 100, Hot 100 Airplay, Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs, [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay]], [[Pop 100 Airplay]], [[Top 40 Mainstream]], [[Rhythmic Airplay Chart]], [[Hot Dance Club Songs]], and [[Hot Ringtones]]. *[[June 9]]–11 – [[Download Festival]] 2006. [[Tool (band)|Tool]], [[Metallica]] and [[Guns N' Roses]] headline the main stage. *[[June 12]] – [[Pink Floyd]] announce that they will reunite with former bassist [[Roger Waters]], who left the band in 1985, on July 2 for the [[Live 8]] London concert. This will be the first time the band played together as a quartet since ''The Wall'' tour in 1981, and the first public performance by Pink Floyd since 1994. *[[June 13]] – [[Michael Jackson]] is found not guilty of child molestation. *[[June 14]] – The [[Backstreet Boys]] came back and released their fifth studio album [[Never Gone]] after a nearly 5-year hiatus *[[June 15]] – [[Destiny's Child]] announce they will disband upon completion of their world tour. *[[June 16]] – [[Motörhead]] celebrate their 30th anniversary with a concert in the [[Hammersmith Apollo]], which is later released on DVD. *[[June 18]]–19 – [[Green Day]] films their first ever live CD/DVD ''[[Bullet in a Bible]]'' at the [[National Bowl]] in [[Milton Keynes]], England. They played to over 130,000 fans in two days. *[[June 21]] – [[Billy Corgan]] announces that he wants to reform his popular [[alternative rock]] group [[The Smashing Pumpkins]], which disbanded on December 2, 2000. *[[June 25]] – [[Patti Smith]] curates the [[Meltdown (festival)|Meltdown festival]].
===July–August=== *[[July 2]] – [[Live 8]] [[benefit concert]]s are held around the world, as part of the [[Make Poverty History]] campaign. *[[July 4]] – [[The Charlie Daniels Band]] plays (and makes a concert DVD) at Riverfront Park in [[Nashville, Tennessee]] *[[July 6]] – [[Lil' Kim]] is sentenced to a year and a day in prison for lying to a federal grand jury about her knowledge of suspects in a 2001 shooting outside a New York radio station.<ref name="lilkim-sentenced">{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1505262/lil-kim-gets-year-day-prison.jhtml |title=Lil' Kim Gets A Year And A Day In Prison |last1=Harris |first1=Chris |last2=Aswad |first2=Jem |date=July 6, 2005 |work= |publisher=[[MTV]] |accessdate=April 5, 2013}}</ref> *[[July 11]] – [[The Chemical Brothers]] release their single, "[[The Boxer (The Chemical Brothers song)|The Boxer]]". *[[July 21]] – [[Gigantour]] runs through to September 11, a festival organised by [[Megadeth]] frontman [[Dave Mustaine]] with bands including [[Dream Theater]], [[Anthrax (American band)|Anthrax]], [[Fear Factory]] and [[Nevermore]]. *[[August 9]] – [[Staind]] releases ''[[Chapter V (Staind album)|Chapter V]]'', which becomes their third-straight studio album to reach #1 on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] album charts. *[[August 18]] – [[Interscope Records]] reports that [[Eminem]] has entered rehab for dependency on sleep medication. The rapper had canceled the European leg of the [[Anger Management Tour|Anger Management 3 Tour]] two days earlier, citing exhaustion.<ref name="eminem rehab">{{cite web |url=http://top40.about.com/od/news/a/eminemrehab.htm |title=Eminem in Rehab |last1=Lamb |first1=Bill |last2= |first2= |date= |work= |publisher=About.com |accessdate=April 5, 2013}}</ref> A four-year hiatus would ensue until the release of the ''[[Relapse (Eminem album)|Relapse]]'' album in 2009. *[[August 24]]-31 – The UNESCO-sponsored Fifth Sharq Taronalari (Melodies of the East) International Music Festival is held in Samarkand.<ref>[http://www.azer.com/aiweb/categories/magazine/ai133_folder/133_articles/133_tashkent.html Azerbaijan International, August 2005]. Accessed 8 Sept 2014</ref> *[[August 26]] – [[Rihanna]] releases her debut album ''[[Music of the Sun]]'', which debuts at number 10 on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. The album produced two singles that achieved international chart success, including first single "[[Pon de Replay]]", which topped number 2 at the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. *[[August 28]] – [[Death Row Records]] CEO [[Suge Knight]] is shot in the leg at an [[MTV Video Music Awards]] pre-party in Miami.<ref name="suge-knight">{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1508497/suge-knight-recovering-after-being-shot-miami.jhtml |title=Suge Knight Recovering After Being Shot At Kanye West Party In Miami |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=August 28, 2005 |work= |publisher=[[MTV]] |accessdate=April 6, 2013}}</ref> No one is ever charged in the shooting.
===September–October=== *[[September 2]] **A statue of [[Edward Elgar]] by Jemma Pearson is unveiled near Hereford Cathedral. **''[[A Concert for Hurricane Relief]]'' airs on NBC and its affiliates, the first of several benefit concerts held to raise funds for [[Hurricane Katrina]] relief efforts. ''[[Shelter from the Storm: A Concert for the Gulf Coast]]'' and ''[[ReAct Now: Music & Relief]] air the following week. ''[[From the Big Apple to the Big Easy]]'', a pair of simultaneous benefit concerts at [[Madison Square Garden]] and [[Radio City Music Hall]], are held on September 20. On A Concert for Hurricane Relief, rapper [[Kanye West]] makes controversial statement, "[[George W. Bush|George Bush]] doesn't care about black people". *[[September 9]] – The band [[Scooter (band)|Scooter]] perform at the All-State Arena in Chicago, IL, their first performance in the United States. *[[September 10]] – Destiny's Child breaks up after the finishing of their Destiny Fulfilled...and Lovin' it Tour. *[[September 20]] – [[J.D. Fortune]] wins ''[[Rock Star: INXS]]'', a reality TV singing contest to become the new lead vocalist of Australian rock band [[INXS]]. *[[September 27]] – American rock band [[Panic! at the Disco]] released their debut album "[[A Fever You Can't Sweat Out]]". Actor [[Drake Bell]] releases his debut musical album ''[[Telegraph (album)|Telegraph]]''. Dancehall artist [[Sean Paul]] releases his third album titled ''[[The Trinity (album)|The Trinity]]''. *[[October 1]] **[[Sentenced]] plays their final show. **[[Akcent]] releases their first single (and video) from their album [[French Kiss with Kylie]] entitled Kylie. *[[October 4]] – [[J.D. Fortune]] releases his first single with [[INXS]] called [[Pretty Vegas]] *[[October 15]] – Media reported that Latin star [[Luis Miguel]] has released his own vintage of wine, "Unico. Luis Miguel", a [[Cabernet Sauvignon]]. *[[October 21]] – [[Nightwish]] perform at the [[Hartwall Areena]], later to be released as the ''[[End of an Era (album)|End of an Era]]'' DVD. The following day, singer [[Tarja Turunen]] is dismissed in an open letter.<ref>[http://www.nightwish.com/en/article/6 Nightwish – The Official Website<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140418020736/http://www.nightwish.com/en/article/6 |date=2014-04-18 }}</ref> *[[October 25]] – [[NSYNC]] releases their first compilation album [[Greatest Hits (NSYNC album)|''Greatest Hits'']] three years after their breakup. *[[October 31]] – ''[[Greatest Hits (Blink-182 album)|Greatest Hits]]'' is released. It is a collection of [[Blink-182]]'s greatest singles. At the time of the release, [[Blink-182]] were on an indefinite hiatus but would later reunite in 2009 and release their sixth studio album ''[[Neighborhoods (Blink-182 album)|Neighborhoods]]'' in 2011.
===November=== *[[November 5]], guitarist [[Link Wray]] of the Ray Men dies at age 76 in Copenhagen, Denmark *[[November 6]] – [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] earns her 36th Top Ten single with [[Warner Bros. Records]]-based, ABBA-sampled "[[Hung Up]]". This ties her with [[Elvis Presley]] for the most Top Ten singles. [[The Beatles]] have 34. "[[Hung Up]]" is also Madonna's 47th Top Forty single – the most for any female artist. Her new album ''[[Confessions on a Dance Floor|Confessions On A Dance Floor]]'' hits #1 in 40 countries during the month, a new record. (The Beatles also previously held this record when ''[[1 (The Beatles album)|The Beatles 1]]'' went to #1 in 36 countries in 2000.) *[[November 8]] – The first ''[[Guitar Hero (video game)|Guitar Hero]]'' video game is released for the [[PlayStation 2]]. The game becomes a major hit that turns [[rhythm game]]s into one of the most popular video game genres for several years, and increases the sales of artists who have their songs included in the games. *[[November 15]] **The [[Sony BMG copy protection rootkit scandal]] breaks as [[Sony BMG]] announces that it will recall all remaining stock of an estimated 15 million CDs containing copy protection that exposes the computers of consumers to serious security risks if played in their PC disc drives. Several class action lawsuits are filed against Sony in the ensuing public relations disaster.<ref name="sony rootkit">{{cite web |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/125838/article.html |title=Settlement Ends Sony Rootkit Case |last1=McMillan |first1=Robert |last2= |first2= |date=May 23, 2006 |work= |publisher=[[PC World]] |accessdate=April 5, 2013}}</ref> **All-female group [[Danity Kane]] is formed on MTV show ''Making The Band''. *[[November 20]] – [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s Warner Bros. Records-based (Festival Mushroom Records in Australia) single, "[[Hung Up]]" takes the title as the ARIA #1 single. *[[November 21]] – [[Kate DeAraugo]] takes the title of ''[[Australian Idol]]'' 2005, ahead of [[Emily Williams]]. *[[November 22]] **The 33rd annual [[American Music Award]]s are held. Multiple winners are [[Destiny's Child]], [[Tim McGraw]], [[Kelly Clarkson]], [[The Black Eyed Peas]], and [[Green Day]]. **[[System of a Down]] becomes the third musical act to have two number 1 albums in the same year. The other two to do this record were [[DMX (rapper)|DMX]] & [[The Beatles]]. ** [[Britney Spears]] releases her first [[remix album]], [[B in the Mix: The Remixes]]. The album had sold 1 millon copies worldwide, making it one of the [[List of best-selling remix albums worldwide|best selling remix album of all time]]. *[[November 29]] – [[Chris Brown]] comes onto the music scene at age 16 with the release of his debut album [[Chris Brown (album)|''Chris Brown'']]. Making him the second youngest male R&B artist to come into the music business since [[Usher (entertainer)|''Usher'']] in 1994. *[[November 30]] – [[Apocalyptica]] change locations of the shoot of their DVD "The Life Burns Tour" from [[Erfurt]], Germany (Dec. 2) to [[Düsseldorf]], Germany (Dec. 4) due to technical reasons.
===December=== *[[December 3]] – [[Marilyn Manson]] and [[Dita Von Teese]] hold a wedding ceremony in Ireland. *[[December 6]] – [[Korn]]'s seventh studio album, [[See You on the Other Side (Korn album)|See You on the Other Side]], debuts at number 3 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. This is the first album without longtime guitarist [[Brian "Head" Welch]] and is the last to feature original drummer [[David Silveria]]. *[[December 7]] – The nominations for the 48th [[Grammy Award]]s are announced. The top-nominated artists include [[Mariah Carey]], [[John Legend]], and [[Kanye West]], with eight nominations each. Other nominated artists include [[Gwen Stefani]], [[Beyoncé Knowles]] (two of her own, plus four with [[Destiny's Child]]), [[Kelly Clarkson]], and [[50 Cent]]. *[[December 10]] **[[Amnesty International]] launches its "[[Make Some Noise (campaign)|Make Some Noise]]" music initiative. **The Los Angeles radio station [[KROQ-FM]] airs the 16th annual [[KROQ Almost Acoustic Christmas|Acoustic Christmas]]. On November 10, 2005, KROQ's official website announced that it will include [[Avenged Sevenfold]], [[Fall Out Boy]], [[Korn]], [[Nine Inch Nails]], [[Rise Against]], [[System of a Down]] and [[Thrice]] for the first night. The second night is held the following day, as also announced at KROQ's official website on November 15, 2005 and includes [[The Bravery]], [[Coldplay]], [[Death Cab for Cutie]], [[Depeche Mode]], [[Hot Hot Heat]], [[Jack Johnson (musician)|Jack Johnson]], [[Nada Surf]] and [[The White Stripes]]. *[[December 11]] – [[Peter Wichers]] leaves [[Soilwork]]. *[[December 15]] – [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s Warner Bros. Records-based single, "[[Hung Up]]" sets a new record in the download charts by staying at #1 for 7 consecutive weeks. The single first appears on Z100 New York, closely followed by 2Day FM (Sydney), Fox FM (Melbourne) and Nova 96.9 (Sydney) other stations follow including: [[KIIS 106.5|Mix 106.5]] (Sydney), [[KIIS 101.1|Mix 101.1]] (Melbourne), [[Smooth 95.3|Vega 95.3]] (Sydney), [[Smooth 91.5|Vega 91.5]] (Melbourne) and the rest of the MIX FM stations. *[[December 21]] – [[Elton John]] marries [[David Furnish]] in London. This marriage comes in the wake of new British laws affording gay unions the same legal protection enjoyed within straight marriages. *[[December 31]] **[[Mariah Carey]] earns her 17th #1 single with "[[Don't Forget About Us]]", tying with Elvis for second as the act with the most #1 singles. [[The Beatles]] have 20. She also becomes the first act to perform live in [[Times Square]] on the [[Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve]] television special on this day. **[[Glue Gun (band)|Glue Gun]] reforms after eight years, with frontman Bob Oedy the only original member. The new line-up is Bob Oedy (vocals), Joey Rimicci (guitars), Brian Priess (bass) and Andy Alverez (drums). Rimicci and Priess were previously members of [[Jughead's Revenge]].

{{use mdy dates|date=December 2011}} {{use American English|date=August 2014}} {{infobox magazine | image_file = ARTnews Cover February 2014.jpg | image_alt = | image_caption = February 2014 cover of ''ARTnews'' | publisher = | editor = Sarah Douglas<ref name="ng"/> | editor_title = | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | category = Visual arts | frequency = Quarterly | format = | total_circulation = 180,000 | circulation_year = 2013 | founder = James Clarence Hyde | founded = | firstdate = {{start date and age|1902|paren=yes}} as ''Hydes Weekly Art News'' | company = [http://www.artmediaholdings.com Art Media Holdings] | country = United States | based = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | language = English | website = {{URL|artnews.com}} | issn = 0004-3273 | oclc = 586878190 }} '''''ARTnews''''' is an American visual-arts magazine, based in [[New York City]]. It covers art from ancient to [[Post-modernism|contemporary]] times. It includes news dispatches from correspondents, investigative reports, reviews of exhibitions, and profiles of artists and collectors.
==History and operations== The magazine was founded by James Clarence Hyde in 1902 as '''''Hydes Weekly Art News''''' and was originally published eleven times a year.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Guide to Serial Publications Founded Prior to 1918 and Now Or Recently Current in Boston, Cambridge, and Vicinity|last=Homer|first=Thomas Johnston|publisher=Trustees of the Public Library|year=1922|isbn=|location=Boston, Massachusetts|pages=20|quote=|via=https://books.google.com/books?id=2qVEAQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA20&ots=rVDu3_6L2G&dq=artnews%201902&pg=PA20#v=onepage&q=artnews%201902&f=false}}</ref><ref>[http://www.copyideas.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/mcleans_1902.pdf "McLean’s 1902 Letter"] [[PDF|PDF format]].</ref>
From vol. 3, no. 52 (November 5, 1904) to vol. 21, no. 18 (February 10, 1923), the magazine was published as '''''American Art News'''''.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Guide to Serial Publications Founded Prior to 1918 and Now Or Recently Current in Boston, Cambridge, and Vicinity|last=Homer|first=Thomas Johnston|publisher=Trustees of the Public Library|year=1922|isbn=|location=Boston, Massachusetts|pages=20|quote=|via=https://books.google.com/books?id=2qVEAQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA20&ots=rVDu3_6L2G&dq=artnews%201902&pg=PA20#v=onepage&q=artnews%201902&f=false}}</ref>From February 1923 to the present, the magazine has been published as ''The Art News'' then ''ARTnews''.<ref>[http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/746445 ARTNews], National Library of Australia.</ref>
The magazine's [[art critic]]s and correspondents include [[Arthur Danto]], Linda Yablonsky, Barbara Pollock, Margarett Loke, Hilarie Sheets, [[Yale School of Art]] dean [[Robert Storr (art academic)|Robert Storr]],<ref>Staff (undated). [http://newyorkmetro.com/news/features/influentials/16900/ "The Most Influential Americans in Art"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720001527/http://newyorkmetro.com/news/features/influentials/16900 |date=July 20, 2008 }}. ''New York''. Retrieved August 10, 2014.</ref> Doug McClemont and [[Museum of Modern Art]] director [[Glenn D. Lowry]].<ref name="nyt2007">{{registration required|date=August 2014}} [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/16/arts/design/16moma.html "Donors Sweetened Director's Pay at MoMA"]. February 16, 2007. ''The New York Times''.</ref>
In April 2014, Milton and Judith Esterow, the magazine's owners since 1972, sold the publication to Skate Capital Corp., a private asset-management firm owned by Sergey Skaterschikov.<ref><!--{{Dead link|date=August 2014}}-->{{registration required|date=August 2014}} Cohen, Patricia (April 8, 2014). [http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/04/08/artnews-sold-to-private-firm/ "ARTnews Sold to Private Company"]. ''The New York Times''.</ref> It was later revealed that Skate Capital was acting on behalf of the Polish company Abbey House, which renamed itself ARTNEWS SA.<ref name="ng">{{Cite news|issn=0458-3035|last=Ng|first=David|title= ARTnews Magazine Gets New Leadership, With a Twist|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=August 10, 2014|date=June 27, 2014|url= http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-artnews-magazine-new-leadership-20140627-story.html}}</ref>
Following this change in ownership the magazine merged with ''[[Art in America]]'' in June 2015, owned by Brant Publication's BMP Media Holdings, LLC.<ref name="sarc"/> In October 2015 the monthly frequency of ''ARTnews'' was switched to quarterly.<ref name="sarc">{{cite news|author=Sarah Cascone|title=‘ARTnews’ Magazine Ceases Monthly Print Publication After 113 Years|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/artnews-quarterly-after-merger-339030|accessdate=December 10, 2016|work=ARTnet|date=October 9, 2015}}</ref> In 2016, Brant Publications took full control of BMP.<ref>{{Cite web| title = BMP Media Holdings Completes Transaction to Assume U.S. Assets of Artnews S.A.| accessdate = 2018-02-19| date = 2016-05-27| url = https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160526006566/en/BMP-Media-Holdings-Completes-Transaction-Assume-U.S.}}</ref>
The magazine, along with ''[[Art in America]]'', ''[[The Magazine ANTIQUES]]'', and ''Modern Magazine'' have been owned by [http://www.artmediaholdings.com Art Media Holdings] since June 2016 and are based in Soho, New York City.

==The ''ARTNews'' Top 200 Collectors== The ''ARTNews'' Top 200 list is released annually and contains the top individual art collectors from around the world based on interviews with collectors, curators, dealers, auction houses, and museums. Those on the list are also surveyed, and their responses are used to inform trends and provide data, such as a breakdown of where the most top art collectors live (the United States<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2013/07/11/where-do-the-worlds-top-art-collectors-live/|title=Where do the world's top art collectors live|last=|first=|date=|website=Foreign Policy|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref>).
Collectors on the list are profiled with a brief biography focused on the type of art that they collect (contemporary, post war, modern, etc.) and includes their city or cities of residence, a photo, their source of wealth and the years they have been on the Top 200 list, as many collectors are on it for multiple years. The list released in September 2018 includes [[Leonard Lauder]], Edythe and [[Eli Broad]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200/edythe-l-and-eli-broad/|title=ARTNews Top 200: Edythe and Eli Broad|last=|first=|date=|website=Art News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref>, [http://www.artnews.com/top200/eisenberg-family/ Rebecca and Warren Eisenberg], [http://www.artnews.com/top200/alison-and-peter-w-klein/ Alison and Peter Klein], Marsha and [[Jeffrey E. Perelman|Jeffrey Perelman]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200/marsha-and-jeffrey-perelman/|title=ARTNews Top 200 Collectors: Marsha and Jeffrey Perelman|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref>, [http://www.artnews.com/top200/tatsumi-sato/ Tatsumi Sako], Sheri and [[Howard Schultz]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200/sheri-and-howard-schultz/|title=ARTNews Top 200 Collectors: Sheri and Howard Schultz|last=|first=|date=|website=Art News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref>. The full list is announced in both the print and online versions of the magazine.

{{Infobox artwork/wikidata |image = A Needle Woman PS1.jpg | caption = PS1 MoMA, exhibition view, 2001 |onlysourced=yes}} '''A Needle Woman''' is a performance video artwork created by artist [[Kimsooja]]. The videos projected simultaneously that comprise [[Kimsooja]]’s ''A Needle Woman'' (1999) presents the artist wearing precisely the same clothes, standing precisely the same way, and, it would seem, at the same time of day in various urban environments.<ref name=Madoff>Madoff, Steven Henry, “Gnomon of Place, Gnomon of foreignness.” Host & Guest catalogue for group exhibition at Tel Aviv Museum of Art, 2013</ref> == History == A Needle Woman premiered at CCA Kitakyushu in 1999. In the Kitakyshu version the artist presented a video channel where she lied on top of a rock formation, as Kimsooja explained “When I was invited to make a new commissioned work at the Center for Contemporary Art in Kitakyushu, Japan, I thought I would do a performance piece - one in the city of Tokyo, and the other one in nature. Then I would juxtapose them together. (…) As a result one was standing still in the middle of a crowd, while the other was lying down on a rock, facing nature. Verticality and horizontality were a metaphor for a dynamic balance between urban and natural forces.” <ref>Ingrid Commandeur, Kimsooja: Black holes, Meditative Vanishings and Nature as a Mirror of the Universe, in Windflower, Perceptions of Nature, NAI and Kroller-Muller Museum ,2012</ref>In further installations of ''A Needle Woman'' Kimsooja focused on the urban aspect of the work and shot a number of new videos where she stood absolutely still, her back facing the camera, amid passing crowds of inhabitants in Patan, Nepal; Havana, Cuba; N’Djamena, Chad; Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Sana’a, Yemen; Jerusalem, Israel.<ref name=Madoff/>
Kimsooja in these videos is often described as a nomadic figure traveling across the world to come to rest in a crowded thoroughfare. The Needle referred to in the title is Kimsooja theorizing herself as a needle passing through the fabric of a place and its people. A common feature of the locations visited in the work is that they are all places of violence, disrepair or unresolved conflict; lending to the needle a metaphoric function as an instrument of suture and healing.<ref name=Madoff/> Subsequent versions of ''A Needle Woman'' were shown at [[MoMA PS1]] Contemporary art center in 2001, at the [[Kunsthalle Bern]] in Bern Switzerland in 2001, for the 51st [[Venice Biennale]] as part of the [[Arsenale]] in 2005, and was projected as a single channel public art project for La Nuit Blanche on the facade of [[Hôtel de Ville, Paris|Hotel de Ville]], Paris in 2009 <ref>Kimsooja Biography: http://www.kimsooja.com/biography.html</ref>

{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Batlló Majesty MNAC.jpg | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 300px | title = Batlló Majesty | alt = Batlló Majesty | type = sculpture | artist = Unknown | year = mid-12th century | material = Carving in walnut (head and body), willow (right arm), elm (cross upright) and holm oak (cross arms) with polychrome tempera | height_metric = 156 | width_metric = 119 | length_metric = 20.5 | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | city = [[Barcelona]] | museum = [[Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya]] | coordinates = | owner = }} The '''''Batlló Majesty''''' ({{lang-ca|Majestat Batlló}}, {{IPA-ca|məʒəsˈtad bəˈʎːo|pron}}) is a large 12th-century [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] wooden [[crucifix]], now in the [[National Art Museum of Catalonia]] in [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]]. It is one of the most elaborate examples in [[Catalonia]] of an image of Christ on the Cross symbolizing his triumph over death.
== History == The Batlló Majesty is a 12th-century Romanesque [[polychrome]] wood carving now in the [[Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya]] in Barcelona, [[Catalonia]]. The Batlló Majesty is one of the finest and best-preserved examples of these Catalan sculptures. Carved wooden images were a fundamental element in churches as objects of worship. One of the most elaborate types in Catalonia was the [[Christ in Majesty]], images of Christ on the Cross that symbolize his triumph over death, of which the most outstanding is the Batlló Majesty. The frontal geometric composition of the [[tunic]] decorated in circles and floral motifs is reminiscent of the refined [[Byzantine]] and Hispano-Moorish fabrics held in such high esteem in the Christian West during this time. The great reference for this type was the [[Volto Santo]] in [[Lucca]] ([[Tuscany]], [[Italy]]), which was regarded as having miraculous origins and was the object of [[pilgrimage]] and extraordinary devotion from the end of the eleventh century.<ref>[http://art.mnac.cat/?&lang=en Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya Online Collections]</ref>
At the end of the 11th century wood sculpture flourished in Catalonia. Carvers used four main formats to represent the [[Crucifixion of Jesus|Crucifixion]]: # 'Calvaries' where [[Jesus]] is represented on the cross with [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Mary]] and [[Saint Joseph|Joseph]]. # 'Deposition Tableaux', or figures of the good and bad thieves [[Mary Magdalene]], [[John the Apostle]], [[Nicodemus]], and [[Joseph of Arimathea]] # 'Majestats' where large wooden crucifixes showed a triumphant Christ wearing a [[colobium]] (a long sleeveless tunic). # 'Nude Majestats' where Christ is wearing only a [[perizonium]] (loincloth).<ref>Mann, Janice. "A Monumental Catalan Crucifix", Bulletin of the Detroit Institute of Arts, Detroit. 1997, LXXI, 1-2, p.52, fig.9.</ref>
Wood carving workshops were still active in the 12th century in the western part of the region in the high valleys of the [[Pyrenees]] in Catalonia. There are over thirty examples of these large crucifixes, called ''majestats''.<ref>Mann, Janice. "Majestat Batlló", The Art of Medieval Spain, a.d.500-1200, New York, 1993, p.322-324.</ref> The Batlló Majesty has been linked to the region of [[Olot]] near Girona. As with much [[medieval art]], its creator is unknown, although a medieval legend credits [[Nicodemus]] with producing the sculpture soon after the actual [[Crucifixion of Jesus|Crucifixion]], a pious tradition repeated elsewhere in Europe in connection with similar monumental crosses, like the better known Volto Santo in the church of San Martino, Lucca, to which they bear a notable similarity in appearance and date, these Catalan crucifixes were believed to have miraculous powers.<ref>Gertrud Schiller, ''Iconography of Christian Art. Volume 2. The Passion of Jesus Christ.'' Janet Seligman (tr.), Greenwich, CT: New York Graphic Society, 1972: 144-5, 472-3.</ref>
A large number of majestats still exist from the Catalan provinces of [[Girona]], [[Barcelona]] and [[Lleida]], and the French province of [[Roussillon]], such that some scholars believe these are monumental crosses once hung in almost every [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] church built in these regions as [[rood cross]]es.<ref>Mann, Janice. "Majestat Batlló", The Art of Medieval Spain, a.d.500-1200, New York, 1993, p.322-324.</ref> It is possible that the ''Majestats'' were the focus of an important and popular cult veneration in these regions as early as the tenth century. They were normally hung near portals of the churches or altars dedicated to the Savior. Often the backs of the majestats were painted with the [[Agnus Dei]] and the Evangelist's symbols suggesting that these crosses were also carried in processions.<ref>Mann, Janice. "Majestat Batlló", The Art of Medieval Spain, a.d.500-1200, New York, 1993, p.322-324.</ref>
Probably it comes from a church in the district of [[Garrotxa]] (Girona). It entered the museum's collection donated by Enric Batlló to the [[Province of Barcelona]] on a permanent loan, 1914. Its inventory Number is 015937-000.
== Description == [[File:Majestat Batlló.jpg|thumb|left|Detail of the ''corpus'']] The cross was procured for the museum in 1914 by the collector Enric Batlló, for whom the piece is now named. It was also the same family that commissioned the construction of Casa Batlló in 1877 Barcelona, Catalonia. At the time of its first arrival at the museum, it was covered with a thick coating of [[varnish]] that obscured but helped preserve its bright colors, which have now been restored.<ref>Trens, M., (1966) Les majestats catalanes, ( Monumenta Cataloniae, XIII) Barcelona p. 161</ref>
Recent studies have revealed the pigments used to produce the colors: the red from [[cinnabar]] and the blue from [[lapis lazuli]]. Both pigments were very expensive and the sculpture is believed to have come from a studio of some importance perhaps the studio around the monastery of [[Ripoll]].<ref>[http://art.mnac.cat/?&lang=en Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya Online Collections]</ref>
== Iconography == The Batlló Majesty presents Christ bearing his suffering with noble stoicism. It is a triumphant Christ wearing a [[colobium]], or a long, sleeveless tunic. Although the corners of his mouth turn slightly downward, Christ's open eyes and unfurrowed brow create the impression of a self-possessed impassivity. One of the striking features of the Batlló Majesty compared to others, is the well-conserved polychromy. Christ’s colobium, in imitation of rich oriental silk, is decorated with blue floral designs surrounded by circular red frames embellished with dots and circles. A thin belt with an elaborate [[interlace (art)|interlace]] knot pulls the tunic in above Christ’s hips, making the fabric above it swell out slightly and curving the path of its flat, wide vertical folds. Such robes, called [[colobium]]s are linked with royal and priestly functions and provide a message of strength to the viewing audience. They can be seen as a visualization of image of the Apocalyptic Christ from the [[Book of Revelation]].<ref>Schiller, Gertrud , Iconography of Cristian Art, Volume II, (1972) London, {{ISBN|0853313245}}, pp.144-145</ref> The [[iconography|iconographic]] tradition of Jesus in a colobium dates to 586 in a manuscript of the Syriac Gospels called the [[Rabbula Gospels]], written by the [[monk]] Rabbula somewhere in [[Mesopotamia]]. It is thought that the tradition of depicting Christ in such costume was brought to Catalonia by artisans from [[Pisa]] who arrived in 1114 to help [[Ramon Berenguer III, Count of Barcelona]] in his conquest of the [[Balearic Islands]].<ref>PIJOÁN, José, (1927), Historia general del arte, Volumen IX, colección Summa Artis. El arte románico siglos XI y XII, p. 505</ref>
A Latin inscription above his head reads, "JHS NAZARENUS REX IUDEORUM" ("Jesus of Nazareth King of the Jews”) as in biblical accounts ([[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] 27:37, [[Gospel of Mark|Mark]] 15:26, [[Gospel of Luke|Luke]] 23:38, [[Gospel of John|John]] 19:19).
== Chronology == The chronology of the Batlló Majesty is difficult to date, but the inscription on the cross and the painting could be placed in the eleventh century, although other authors dating back to the twelfth century based on the painting’s similarity to ones seen in the area of Ripoll, mid-twelfth century, which is used as an argument to support this dating, and can now be placed into 1150. The tunic also has an analogy with an Islamic motif abacus of the cloister of the abbey of Saint-Pierre de [[Moissac]], which seems to prove the spread during the Romanesque period.

{{Multiple issues| {{missing information|the film's production, and theatrical release|date=August 2015}} {{more citations needed|date=August 2015}} }} {{Infobox film | name = Black Like Me | image = File:BlackLikeMe.1964.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = Carl Lerner | producer = Julius Tannenbaum | screenplay = Carl Lerner
[[Gerda Lerner]] | based on = {{Based on|''[[Black Like Me]]''|[[John Howard Griffin]]}} | starring = [[James Whitmore]] | music = [[Meyer Kupferman]] | cinematography = Victor Lukens
Henry Mueller II | editing = Lora Hays | studio = The Hilltop Company | distributor = [[Continental Distributing]] | released = {{Film date|1964|05|20}} | runtime = 107 minutes{{rotten-tomatoes|black_like_me|Black Like Me}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Black Like Me''''' (1964) is an American drama film based on the book ''[[Black Like Me]]'' by [[John Howard Griffin]]. The journalist disguised himself to pass as an African-American man for six weeks in 1959 in the Deep South to report on life in the segregated society from the other side of the color line. The film was directed by [[Gerda Lerner|Carl Lerner]] and the screenplay was written by Carl and [[Gerda Lerner]]. The film stars [[James Whitmore]], [[Sorrell Booke]] and [[Roscoe Lee Browne]]. The DVD was released December 11, 2012 in North America from Video Services Corp. The DVD includes a documentary titled ''Uncommon Vision'' about John Howard Griffin, the journalist on which the main character is based.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/59958/black-like-me|title=Black Like Me: DVD Talk Review of the DVD Video|date=February 14, 2013|accessdate=November 10, 2013|website=DVD Talk|last=Hartel|first=Nick|at=The DVD: The Extras|deadurl=no|quote=The film's bonus disc features a 60-min feature length documentary, ''Uncommon Vision: The Life and Times of John Howard Griffin'' on the film's real-life subject.}} ==Plot== {{expand section|date=August 2015}} John Finley Horton ([[James Whitmore]]) is a white journalist who artificially darkens his skin in order to pass for a black man. He travels for several weeks in the Deep South in order to report from the other side of the color line in the segregated society. He spends time in places from New Orleans to Atlanta, and encounters racism from both white and black people. ==Cast== * [[James Whitmore]] as John Finley Horton (''[[Black Like Me]]'' author [[John Howard Griffin]]) * [[Sorrell Booke]] as Dr. Jackson * [[Roscoe Lee Browne]] as Christopher * [[Al Freeman, Jr.]] as Thomas Newcomb * [[Will Geer]] as truck driver * [[Robert Gerringer]] as Ed Saunders * [[Clifton James]] as Eli Carr * [[John Marriott (actor)|John Marriott]] as Hodges * [[Thelma Oliver]] as Georgie * [[Lenka Peterson|Lenka Petersen]] as Lucy Horton ==Reception== {{expand section|date=September 2015}} Critical reception for the film has been mixed. Bosley Crowther of ''The New York Times'' described the film as "melodramatic and unsubtle". He said it failed to place the viewer inside a Negro's skin, and to convince the audience that the protagonist "is truly passing for black".{{cite web|last1=Crowther|first1=Bosley|title=Black Like Me (1964) James Whitmore Stars in Book's Adaptation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9A0CE5DD1F3AE13ABC4951DFB366838F679EDE|website=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=8 September 2015}} Reviewing the film after the 2012 DVD release, Leonard Maltin awarded the film a positive 3 out of 4 stars. He said that, although some aspects of the film felt dated, the film's themes were still timely.{{cite book|author=[[Maltin, Leonard]]|title=Leonard Maltin's 2014 Movie Guide|date=2014|publisher=[[Penguin Press]]|location=New York, New York|isbn=978-0-451-41810-4|page=138}} ==Release== {{expand section|date=September 2015}} The film made its DVD debut on February 12, 2002 by VCI Home Video. It later was re-released by Video Service Corp on December 11, 2012.{{cite web|title=Black Like Me (1964) - Carl Lerner|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/black-like-me-v5893/releases|website=Allmovie.com|publisher=AllMovie|accessdate=8 September 2015}} ==See also== *[[List of American films of 1964]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0057889}} * {{allrovi movie|5893|Black Like Me}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|black_like_me|Black Like Me}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Black Like Me}} [[Category:1964 films]] [[Category:1960s drama films]] [[Category:African-American civil rights movement (1954–68) in film]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:African-American films]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films about racism]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films based on non-fiction books]] [[Category:Films set in Atlanta]] [[Category:Films set in New Orleans]] [[Category:Films set in Texas]] [[Category:Films set in the 1950s]] [[Category:Films shot in Florida]] [[Category:Films shot in New York (state)]] [[Category:Films shot in Washington, D.C.]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Booknotes | image = Booknotes logo C-SPAN 200.jpg | caption = | genre = [[Talk show]] | creator = | developer = | presenter = [[Brian Lamb]] | starring = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 16 | num_episodes = 801 | list_episodes = | producer = | executive_producer = | location = | camera = | runtime = 60 minutes | network = [[C-SPAN]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = {{Start date|1989|4|2}} | last_aired = {{End date|2004|12|5}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = http://www.booknotes.org }} '''''Booknotes''''' is an [[Television in the United States|American]] [[television series]] on the [[C-SPAN]] [[television network|network]] hosted by [[Brian Lamb]], which originally aired from 1989 to 2004.<ref name=Boston>{{cite news |title='Booknotes' Afterword |newspaper=The Boston Globe |date=19 August 2004}}</ref> The format of the show is a one-hour, one-on-one [[interview]] with a [[non-fiction]] author.<ref name=Heltzel>{{cite news |title=Books On TV, and a Host Who Listens |author=Ellen Emry Heltzel |newspaper=The Sunday Oregonian |date=17 August 1997}}</ref> The series was broadcast at 8 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Time]] each Sunday night,<ref name=Prial>{{cite news |title=After Many Million Pages, 'Booknotes' Ends Its Run |author=Frank J. Prial |newspaper=The New York Times |date=4 December 2004 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/04/arts/television/04lamb.html |accessdate=4 November 2010}}</ref> and was the longest-running author interview program in U.S. broadcast history.
==Background and production==
===History=== ''Booknotes'' debuted on April 2, 1989. The first guest was former [[United States National Security Advisor]] [[Zbigniew Brzezinski]], discussing ''The Grand Failure: The Birth and Death of Communism in the Twentieth Century''.<ref name=Wilcox>{{cite news |title=Books on TV: a time line |author=Dave Wilcox |newspaper=Fort Worth Star-Telegram |date=September 16, 1998}}</ref> The fifth anniversary was marked on April 10, 1994 with a special two-hour show featuring over 50 of the 300 authors previously featured on the program.<ref name=Moore>{{cite news |title='Booknotes' Series Marks 5th Chapter With C-SPAN Special |author=Frazier Moore |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date=9 April 1994}}</ref> For the tenth anniversary of ''Booknotes'' in 1999, Brian Lamb compiled and edited an anthology of stories on 78 people who influenced American history from the 18th century to 1999. Titled ''Booknotes: Life Stories'', each contributed story was written by a well-known biographer.<ref name=Milwaukee>{{cite news |title=There's no time for TV for C-SPAN founder Lamb |newspaper=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel |date=25 May 1999}}</ref>
After 801 interviews, the final broadcast aired December 5, 2004.<ref name=Prial/> Lamb's guest was [[Mark Edmundson]], author of ''Why Read?'', professor of English at the [[University of Virginia]] and a contributing editor at ''[[Harper's Magazine]]''.<ref name=Biffle>{{cite news |title=The Last Author Of One Last Book For One Final Hour |author=Tony Biffle |newspaper=The Sun Herald |date= 5 December 2004}}</ref> The show was intended to end with the 800th episode, but due to a miscalculation, the final program was actually the 801st.<ref name=Biffle/>
''Booknotes'' segments continue to be re-aired on [[C-SPAN]]'s companion network C-SPAN 2, during Saturday ''[[Book TV]]'' broadcasts,<ref name=Advocate>{{cite news |title="Booknotes" was benefit for books |newspaper=The Advocate |date=11 December 2004 }}</ref> while C-SPAN 3 airs repeat segments every weeknight at 11 p.m. [[Pacific Time Zone|Pacific Time]]. All 801 transcripts are available online<ref name=Boston/> and the 801 shows can be viewed online via the ''Booknotes'' website.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://booknotes.org/home/index.asp |title=Booknotes archive |work=Booknotes.org |publisher=C-SPAN |accessdate=19 October 2010}}</ref> Lamb's own copies of the ''Booknotes'' books, most of which contain his personal [[marginalia]], are housed in the rare books collection of [[George Mason University]].<ref name=Kelly>{{cite news |title=In Brian Lamb's 'Booknotes' marginalia, a record of our time's serious thoughts |author=John Kelly |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/in-brian-lambs-booknotes-marginalia-a-record-of-our-times-serious-thoughts/2011/09/21/gIQA8EwzlK_story.html |work=The Washington Post |date=21 September 2011 |accessdate=28 September 2011}}</ref>
===Development=== The ''Booknotes'' concept grew out of a one-off interview special with [[Neil Sheehan]], author of ''[[A Bright Shining Lie]]'', in September 1988.<ref name=Milwaukee/> The interview itself resulted from Lamb having viewed a short [[Commercial broadcasting|commercial television]] interview with Sheehan and wanting to hear more.<ref name=Milwaukee/> According to Lamb, a strong viewer response to the program led to the decision to start producing a weekly author interview program.<ref name=Prial/>
===Format=== Each ''Booknotes'' episode devoted one full hour to an interview with the author of a recently released non-fiction book.<ref name="Heltzel"/> In order to avoid duplicate appearances by any one author, each guest appeared only once on the program,<ref name=Prial/> thus allowing for over 800 different authors to be interviewed every week over a fifteen-year stretch. The hour-long interviews explored authors' work habits, thoughts and lives, while also covering the intentions of their book and how, or if, these were achieved.<ref name="Boston"/><ref name="Heltzel"/>
===Production=== Research for the interviews was simple: producers identified subjects, arranged for them to appear and Brian Lamb would then read the book in the week prior to the interview.<ref name=Milwaukee/> One reason for discontinuing the series, according to Lamb, was the time constraints imposed by reading an entire book every seven days.<ref name=Prial/>
The set where ''Booknotes'' was recorded was similarly basic, comprising a black backdrop, two armchairs and a coffee table.<ref name=Advocate/>
===Awards=== In February 2003, Lamb was awarded the [[National Humanities Medal]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.neh.gov/news/report2002/medals.html|title= National Humanities Medal|accessdate=15 November 2008 |work= 2002 Annual Report|publisher= [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] Official site}}</ref> In November 2007, Lamb received the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] for his work on C-SPAN.<ref>{{cite news |title= Citations Recipients of the Presidential Medal of Freedom|url= https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/11/20071105-7.html|publisher= The White House: Official Site|date= 5 November 2007|accessdate=13 November 2008}}</ref> The [[American Historical Association]] awarded Lamb the 2004 Theodore Roosevelt-Woodrow Wilson Award "for extraordinary contributions to the study, teaching, and public understanding of history."<ref>see [http://www.historians.org/prizes/AWARDED/RooseveltWilsonWinner/04Lamb.cfm announcement]</ref>
==Guests== Notable guests appearing on ''Booknotes'' to discuss their published writings have included [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Pat Buchanan]], [[Colin Powell]], [[Frank McCourt]] and [[David Crosby]].<ref name=Boston/> A number of former presidents have appeared on the program, including [[Richard Nixon]] on February 23, 1992, [[Jimmy Carter]] on February 19, 1995 and [[Bill Clinton]] on December 15, 1996.<ref name=Wilcox/> In addition to the U.S. presidents who were interviewed for ''Booknotes'', former [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|UK Prime Minister]] [[Margaret Thatcher]] also appeared on the program.<ref name=Moore/>
While the majority of ''Booknotes'' subjects have been authors of books on history, politics or public policy, exceptions included the violinist [[Isaac Stern]], who discussed his memoir, ''My First 79 Years'', on the program on January 23, 2000.<ref name=Prial/>
==Books== Including ''Booknotes: Life Stories'', four books have been drawn from the series, with content either comprising original material or taken directly from transcripts of ''Booknotes'' interviews.<ref name=Biffle/> ''Booknotes: America's Finest Authors on Reading, Writing and the Power of Ideas'' is a compilation of short monologues taken from the transcripts of Brian Lamb’s best interviews.<ref name=Heltzel/> The other two books are ''Booknotes: On American Character'' and ''Booknotes: Stories from American History''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://booknotes.org/home/index.asp |title=Booknotes Books |work=Booknotes.org |publisher=C-SPAN |accessdate=19 October 2010}}</ref>

[[Image:Buzzybeeride.JPG|thumb|right|200px|A children's ride in the shape of a Buzzy Bee in [[Warkworth, New Zealand|Warkworth]]]]
The '''Buzzy Bee''' is a popular [[toy]] in [[New Zealand]]. It resembles a [[bee]] with rotating [[wing]]s that move and make a clicking noise while the toy is pulled along the ground. Possibly based on an earlier American concept,<ref name="NZ_Herald_9661">{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=9661 |title=Nasty sting in the tale of 'our' Buzzy Bee icon |date=8 July 1999 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}}</ref> it was designed and first produced in New Zealand in the 1930s, by [[Maurice Schlesinger]].<ref>Williams, Tony (2007). ''101 Incredible Kiwis: How New Zealanders Lead the World.'' Auckland: Reed Publishing.</ref> It became popular during the [[post-war]] [[baby boom]]. Its bright colours and clicking sound call are familiar to many New Zealanders, making it one of the most well-recognised items of [[Kiwiana]]. Since this time however, the Buzzy Bee has branched out into various merchandise including books, jigsaws and clothing.
It received a good deal of free promotion with the visit of [[Charles, Prince of Wales|The Prince]] and [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Princess of Wales]] in 1983 with their infant son, [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William of Wales]], who played with a Buzzy Bee.
As an iconic New Zealand symbol, the Buzzy Bee caricature was used on the keel of NZL84, one of [[Emirates (airline)|Emirates]] [[Team New Zealand]]'s entrant yachts for the [[America's Cup]] held in [[Valencia, Spain]], in 2007.
In June 2007, plans were unveiled for a Buzzy Bee stage show ''"Buzzy Bee's Big Day Out"''. The company behind the show also revealed that they'd made an animated show reel and were finalising details of a distribution deal, and that they hoped to begin work on an animated series for television.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/author/story.cfm?a_id=328&objectid=10441111 |title=Multi-million dollar Buzzy Bee stage show to hit the road |author=Joanna Hunkin |publisher=NZ Herald |date=2007-05-22 |accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref> The animated TV show ''Buzzy Bee and Friends'' has aired on TV2 from 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=TV Show |url=https://buzzybeetv.com/videos/tv/ |work=Buzzy Bee and friends |publisher=Lion Rock Ventures |accessdate=2 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208061906/https://buzzybeetv.com/videos/tv/ |archivedate=8 February 2013 |df= }}</ref>
[[Fisher-Price]] manufactured Buzzy Bees from 1950 to 1956. [http://www.thisoldtoy.com/new-images/images-ok/300-399/fp325-bee.jpg Buzzy Bee] was originally covered with paper lithographs depicting a yellow bee with pink cheeks, blue eyes, and striped tail. The bee had two spring antennae topped with red beads. Yellow acetate wings rotated and the toy made a "buzz-buzz" sound as it was pulled along on two wooden wheels.<ref>[http://www.thisoldtoy.com/L_FP_Set/toy-pages/300-399/325-buzzybee.html Buzzy Bee] This Old Toy</ref><ref name=rich>Rich, Mark. ''Warman's 101 Greatest Baby Boomer Toys.'' kp books, 2005.</ref> Buzzy Bee cost $.59 and was Fisher-Price's first toy to feature plastic. The toy was retired for a few years but returned in 1956 as Queen Buzzy Bee wearing a polyethylene crown. Queen Buzzy was manufactured through the mid-1980s.<ref name=rich />
==References== <references/>
